folders.description: Folder 1. Acer Pseudo-Platanus [G]. i. "Maple. Bulls: [Bulstrode] Park" [JL]

1 folder. Amaranthus Blitum [TA]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 1957. ii. "Blite Amaranth. Aug." It is often found on Dunghills in the neighbourhood of London. I gather'd this on a Dunghill at Fulham near London" [JL]. iii. "Amaranthus Blitum. Monoec: 5. and:" [JL]
Asarum europaeum [TA]. i. "Asarum europaeum Lin: Asarabacca. Anglis. ex horto" [JL].
Cites Ray's Syn. 287. ii. "Water Gladiole. July & August. In the Lakes of North Wales & Westmoreland" [JL]

Cites Ray's Hist. 746. ii. "Caustic Lobelia. Habitat solum humidum & spongiosum Ericeti cujusdam Shute Common dicti Devoniae, inter paludem turfosam & viam publican quae ab Axminster ad Honiton ducit. Plures plantas primum invenit Dom: Newbury e Coll: Exon: Oxon: circiter finem Octobris, Anno 1768" [JL]

Linnaea borealis [JL]. i. Cites Linn. Sp. Pl. 631; Bauh. Pin. 93. ii. "This is a Native of Sweden, Sibiria, Switzerland, Russia, Canada, & c. This Specimen was gathered & communicated by Jos: Banks Esqr. who discover'd it in Abundance in the Woods in Newfoundland" [JL]. iii. "In Scotland—See English Botany N.433" [? G].

Folder 1. Cerastium latifolium [G]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 349. ii. "Cerastium alpinum. This was gathered upon Snowdon at the top of the highest Rock call'd Clogwyn y Garnedh. June" [JL]. iii. "Top of Snowdon" [JL]. iv. "Dr. Solander affirms this to be the true Cerastium alpinum. I had it from Snowdon. He found it at Terra del Fuego & named it C. hirtum with a mark of Dubitation, but now thinks them both one" [JL].
Folder 2. Cerastium alpinum [TA]; Cerastium latifolium [G]. i. "Clogwyn dû" [JL]. ii. "Cerast: alpin: Ben Lomond" [JL].

Folder 1. Cerastium arvense [TA]. i. "Cerastium arvense. This must be right tho' the leaves are hoary" [JL]. ii. "Cerastium arvense. Very common in Norfolk. Why does Lin. put the word glabris in his Specific Description in opposition to truth & the Testimony of all Authors" [B].
Folder 2. Cerastium arvense [G]. [See also under C. arcticum Folder 1.]

species.speciesName: Cerastium fontanum Baumg., subsp. triviale (Link) Jalas, Flora Europaea 1: 142 (1964)

folders.description: Cerastium vulgaris [TA]; C. vulgatum Huds. and C. viscosum Linn. [G]. i. "Pray inform mewhether this be Cerastium vulgaris or Cerast: viscosum, & wch of the Figures in Vaillant: Paris: agrees with it, for Linnaeus & Haller seem to contradict each other. In meadows, June. Mr Banks's vulgaris" [JL].

Sheet 1. Cucubalus baccifer [JL]. i. "Cucubalus bacciferus calyicibus campanulatis, petalis distantibus, pericarpis coloratis, ramis divaricatis. Lin: Syst. Nat. Cucubalus Plinii. R. Syn: 267." ii. "Berry-bearing Chickweed. July & Aug." This plant was found growing spontaneously in the Isle of Man, by Dr. Richardson" [JL]. [On loose label in pencil:] "I. of Dogs" [Riddelsdell].

Dianthus caryophyllus [TA]. i. "Dianthus caryophyllus Lin: Ray Syn: p. 336. no. 3. on Rochester Castle Walls & c." [JL]. ii. "& single Clove mentioned in Ray on Rochester Walls" [?]; "??? is this not from a Garden" [JL].

Folder 1. Dianthus glaucus? [TA]. i. "Dianthus glaucus pro certo. Kew. respondet. fig: Dillen:" [JL]. ii. "This Aiton [William Aiton] says is the Dianthus glaucus. White flowers with a purple Circle. Kew. compare it with Dianth: deltoides" [JL].
Folder 2. Dianthus deltoides [TA]. "Dianthus Deltoides. Salt Hill" [?].
Folder 1. Dianthus arenarius Hud. [TA]. i. "Cheddar brought into a Garden" [JL]. ii. "Dianthus arenarius the true. Sent by Mr. Banks to Bulstrode from Cheddar." [JL].
Folder 2. Dianthus virginicus [TA]; Dianthus arenarius Huds. [G]. i. "Dianth: arenar: Bulstrode. Q: an non idem Mr. Banks's" [JL].

Folder 1. Herniaria glabra [TA]. i. Herniaria glabra. Cites Lin: Sp. Pl: Herniaria; Ray's Syn: 160. ii. "Smooth Rupture-wort. This specimen was gathered from the Lizard Point in Cornwall & communicated by Mr. Hudson" [JL].
Folder 1. Herniaria hirsuta [TA]. i. "Hern: hirsuta according to Yalden" [JL]. ii. "Herniaria hirsuta. Gordon's Garden [?]; D. o. P: [possibly the Duchess of Portland] [JL].

Illecebrum verticillatum [TA]. i. "Illecebrum verticillatum floribus verticillatis nudis, caulibus procumbentibus. Lin: Sp: Pl: Corrigiola. Ray's Syn: 160. Verticillate Knot Grass. July. In Marshes & moist Places about Pensans in Cornwall" [JL]. ii. "The verticillate sample I rec'd from Mr. Banks collected at Pensans, wch I take to be the true Illecib: verticill: but the other seems to be rather Illecib: cymosum, & perhaps the Polygonum maritimum Ray: 161 near Weston. This from Mr. Hudson" [JL].
Folder 1. Dianthus Prolifer [TA]. i. "Dianthus prolifer" [JL]. ii. "Dianthus prolifer of Eaton. Q: July Aug. Kew. In Selsey Island Sussex" [JL].
Folder 1. Agrostema coronaria [TA]. i. "? not English" [TA]. ii. "Tenbigh [Tenby in Dyfed (Pembrokeshire)]" [JL]. [From southeastern Europe, cultivated, locally naturalized elsewhere.]

Folder 1. Arenaria tenuifolia [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 1102 (1777). i. "Arenaria tenuifolia 10- and: 3-g" [JL].

Folder 1. Arenaria verna [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 231, 1140 (1777). i. Cites Lin: Syst: Nat: in Mantissa, page 72; Ger: Provinc: Tab: 15. f: 1.; R: Syn. 350. ii. "Mountain vernal Chickweed. May. Upon the Mountains in Scotland, & the North of England. This Plant is call’d by Hudson Arenaria saxatilis, but I think his Characters of that Species will not agree with the Samples here exhibited, particularly as the Calyces are not obtuse. They are striated & acuminated, & the Figure of Gerard above-cited agrees perfectly well with these Samples" [JL].
Folder 2. Arenaria laricifolia [TA and G]. i. "Scotland, Yalden" [JL].

Folder 1. Silene acaulis [G]. i. Cites Linn. Syst. Nat.; Ray's Syn. 341. ii. "Moss Campion. July. This Plant is a Native of our alpine Mountains in North Wales. It was gathered & communicated by Mr. Williams, from the Top of Clogwyn du yr Ardder, Snowdon in Carnarvonshire, June 16th 1767" [JL].

Folder 2. Silene acaulis [TA]. i. "This from Ben-Lomond" [?]. ii. "Silene anglica by Hudson from Cornwall, common. It is Lusitanica" [JL]. [Label does not belong with specimen; should be on S. gallica Folder 2.]

Folder 1. Silene anglica Huds. [G]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 339. ii. "Small Corn Catchfly or Campion. This was found at Swathling near Stoneham near Southampton, three fields behind Sir Edwd's Hawke's House, among Turnips. It has been found also among Corn near the Devil's Ditch in Cambridgeshire and near Colchester in Essex. June & July. It is an Annual" [JL].
Folder 2. Silene lusitanica [TA]; S. lusitanica Huds. [G]; S. anglica Huds. [G]. i. "Silene Lusitanica pro certo. Penzance" [JL]. [See under S. acaulis Folder 2.]

Cucubalus viscosus [JL]. i. "Cucubalus viscosus. 10- and: 3-g:" [JL]. ii. [On reverse:] "This does not agree with the Linnaean Specimen, wch bears a Spike of flowers with short Peduncles, & The upper Leaves of the Stalks are cordate & sessile" [JL].

Cistus polifolius [G]. i. "Cistus polifolius Lin: I gathered this on Brean-Down near Uphill in Somersetshire at the End of June, 1773" [JL].

Folder 1. Cistus marifolius Lin. [G]; Cistus hirsutus Huds. [G]. i. Cites Linnaeus; Hudson's Fl. Anglica; Ray's Syn. 342. ii. "Hoary dwarf Mountain Cistus, with yellow flowers. July. Ray relates this Plant to have been found on some Rocks near Kendal in Westmorland by M: Newton; also at Buck-Barrow Bank Scar, between Brigsteer and Conswick, & on the Rocks at Cartmel-Wells in Lancashire plentifully. It was sent from the Physic Garden in Oxford to the Princess Dowager's Garden at Kew, from whence I receiv'd it" [JL]. iii. "Cistis marifolius? Lin. ex. horto Kewensis" [JL].
Folder 2. Cistus marifolius [TA]; Linn. [G]; Cistus hirsutus Huds. [G]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 342. ii. "Cistus marifolius? Lin. at Gloddaeth near Carnarvonshire" [JL].

Folder 3. Cistus marifolius Linné [G]; Cistus anglicus [TA] Huds. [G]; Cistus hirsutus Huds. [G]. i. "Helianthemum alpinum folio Pilosellae minoris Fuchsii. Ray. syn. 342. called by Hudson Cistus Hirs tus, & by Linnaeus in the 13th Edit: of Syst. Nat. p. 414, Cistus anglicus, but in all Probability does not differ from the C. marifolius Lin: I gathered it at Gloddaeth near Conway in Carnarvonshire. June" [JL]. ii. "Cistus caulibus duris, procumbensibus, foliiis ellipticis, hirsutis, inferne tomentosis, petiolis con fer tis, unifloris, calycibus tomentosis Haller Helv: Vol: 2. p.4. No. 1035. which he makes to be the Cistus marifolius Lin: Sp. 741. suffraticosus exstipulatus, foliiis oppositis oblongis petiolatis planis subitus incarnis. Flores exigui flavi. Folia ad serram conferta. Burrel: fig: 366agrres best, w:ch Lin: places under his Var. β of Cistus canus. Hudson's Cistus hirsutus, is now made by Lin: Cistus anglicus. Lin: Mantiss: p. 241, but probably without Reason or by Mistake, as he says of it Folia utrinque; viridia, & flores racemosi albi. But neither Leaves nor flowers are so in this. I therefore conclude it to be the C. marifolius. Lin: sp. 741. not the C. canus because the leaves are not obovate, tho' these two are very much alike. Ayton [William Aiton] always receiv'd this kind from abroad for C. marifolius. He suspects C. marifolius w:ch has Leaves like this, & his alpestris to be all varieties of the same species" [JL]. iii. "C. canus Scopoli: No. 647 agrees well with this. He suspects C. marifolius w:ch has Leaves like this, & his alpestris to be all varieties of the same species" [JL]. iv. "C. canus Lin: or a var: of it as I believe. An English species call'd C. hirsutus by Huds." [JL].

Folder 4. Cistus marifolius Linne [G]; Cistus hirsutus Huds. [G]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 342. ii. "Cistus marifolius? Lin. At Gloddaeth near Conway in Carnarvonshire. June" [JL]. iii. "Cistus marifolius? from Gloddaeth. Aiton says he has always rec'd this from abroad for C. marifolius. It always flowers in June a month before the other. Mr. Holland" [JL].

Hieracium murorum [G]. i. "a hybridous Plant between H: murorum & alpinum, or a singular var. of H. alpinum w: 2 flowers. There is not one in Lin. or Haller that agrees. It [on reverse:] cannot be H. dubium because the Stalk is not naked, & the Root has no Stolones" [JL].

Hieracium sabaudum L: f: a Starv'd β [TA].

Turritis hirsuta [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 358 (1777). i. "I must beg Leave, my good Friend, to retract what I mentioned to you concerning the plant I picked up in Glostershire, for on Inspection, I perceived my mistake. I likewise examined Dr. Randolph's Specimens of Cardamine bellidifolia & found them all Turritis hirsuta, tho' He said Dr. Dillenius gave Him one of the Specimens I saw—together w' th the name—I have enclosed a Specimen of the plant I 147 collected which you will easily know—as it is our Election Week all the fellows are up, so that I have scarce time to say how much I am obliged by the curious specimens Mr. Woods brought that I am & always shall be yr. affectionate Friend & Serv. W. Sheffield [Keeper of the Museum at Oxford]. Are you got thro’ the Syngenescallass? Wor-Coll. [presumably Worcester College, Oxford] Friday afternoon” [Sheffield].

Folder 1. Euphorbia exigua [G]. i. "I found this plant, 1773, in our Cornfields, and supposed it to be only a variety of the exigua. I am still of the same opinion. It agrees indeed pretty well with the Tishy-malus Segetum longifolius. Cat. Cant. App & Rall Syn. p.312, since it is there described as Esulae exiguae Tragi persimilis, sed major; *because of the Umbella quinquefida in the one & trifida in the other. The Segetalis in Ray and the Segetalis in Linnaeus are certainly two very different Plants; and I should be glad to know, and I wish it may be in your power to inform me, whether those Specimens, wch Mr. Lyons found near Triplow, be at all different from this Specimen—another circumstance also makes me conclude that it is only a variety of the exigua; because found in company wth it, and am inclined to think that it never will be found anywhere else. I gathered more of it at the same Time; but have either mislaid or shuffled it away. But if I should find the same variety again, I will endeavour to collect the Seed of it, and try what it will do in my Garden. *Supposing all other circumstances equal, the quinquefida must be to the trifida in Magnitude in the Proportion of 5 to 3, wch wants only one third part of being twice as big" [B]. ii. "Euphorbia segetalis of D. Lyons, not of Lin: It seems to be only a Variety of Euphorb: exigua Lin: In Cornfields in Norfolk, Mr. Bryant. I compared this with Lyon's own Specimen, now in the possession of Mr. Banks" [JL].

Geranium maritimum [TA and G]. i. "Flat Holmes & Carnarvonshire" [JL].

"Geranium colubrinum. On the right hand Bank in the first Inclosure in the Road from Heydon upper Common to Corpusty Church [Norfolk]" [B]. iv. "Specimens and labels mixed when received at Kew. C.H.W. 28 March 1921" [C.H. Wright, not identified].

Folder 1. Geranium Sylvaticum [TA]. i. "Geranium sylvaticum Lin: - A D: Bryant. G: batracoides montanum nostras. R. Syn: p. 361. n° 18. found near Spixworth Church, 5 miles from Norwich. This is the Plant figured in Rose's Elem. Botan: Append: tab. 1. under the Name of Geranium palustre?" [JL].
Folder 2. Geranium Sylvaticum [G]. i. "G: sylvaticum. Physic Garden Oxford" [JL]. ii. "At the Foot of Ingleborough" [JL].
Hippuris vulgaris [TA]. i. "Hippuris vulgaris" [JL]. ii. [On loose label:] "Hippuris vulgaris. Mare's tail" [?].

Melittis melissophyllum [TA]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 242. ii. "Bastard Balm. June & July. This is found in the Woods about Totness in Devonshire, Haverford-west in Pembrokeshire, and about Netley Abbey in Hampshire by S' W'm Musgrave" [JL]
Melittis melissophyllum [G]. i. "Melittis melissophyllum. S' Leonard's Forest in Sussex" [JL]
Melittis melissophyllum [G]. i. "Melittis melissophyllum Lin: S' Leonard's Forest, Sussex. May" [JL]

Mentha hirsuta [TA]; M. aquatica Huds. [G]. i. "Mentha hirsuta Lin. syst. nat. 444. Sisymbrium hirsutum. r. Syn. N° 7, seu fortassè N° 8" [JL]. ii. "N° 2. Mentha hirsuta Huds. Staminibus corolla longioribus" [B]; "Bryant. The true M. hirsuta Lin." [JL].

Mentha hirsuta ut variety [TA]; M. aquatica Huds. var. [G]. i. "No 1. Mentha Hirsuta Huds. Found at Norwich" [not Bryant's writing;? Pitchford]; "Bryant" [JL]. ii. "N° 2. N° 1 I begged of M' Pitchford, that I might see what he understood by the Mentha hirsuta Huds., but he can assign no other Reason for it, than that the Stamina are Shorter than the Calyx. His Specimen is the same w' th" [on reverse:] "N° 2, where they are longer" [B]. iii. "this mint from Dr H: [probably Dr Hope] was it found in Scotland?" [JL].

Mentha arvensis [TA]. i. "Langley or Iver Heath" [JL]. ii. "Bryant. right" [JL]; "Mentha arvensis. N° 3. Floribus verticillatis, & staminibus corolla longioribus. In N°s 1,2,3, w' ch are evidently the same Plant, you find all the Marks w' ch constitute the Differences between the arvensis, aquatica, & hirsuta, Huds. the Floribus capitatis therefore is not to be depended upon, no more than the length of the Stamina—and indeed I have found some Instances where the Floribus capitatis & verticillatis have been produced on different Branches from one and the same Root" [B].

Mentha gentilis [JL]. i. "Mentha gentilis Lin: ex horto. In this the Peduncles are smooth & Leaves more acute, approaching to the lanceolate Figures. The Calyces are sprinkl'd with resinous shining Dots" [JL].

species.speciesName: Mentha ×niliaca Juss. et Jacq. var. villosa (Huds.) J.Fraser
species.description: Mentha sylvestris [TA]; Var. Huds. [G]. i. "Mentha sylvestris. Lin: Mentha longifolia. Huds: Between Penryn & Falmouth, Cornwal" [JL]. ii. "Mentha longifolia Huds. Mentha Sylvestris Lin. The Stamina in this Species are shorter than the Corollae. Lin. has made them longer. I suppose because he has seen them so—therefore the Length can be no Rule" [B]; "Bryant" [JL]; "This I take to be the M: longifolia Huds: & M: sylvestris Lin., but the Sample is not very good" [JL]. [Specimen on far left is Mentha ×piperita.].
Mentha sylvestris var. Huds. [G]. i. "[-af]fectionate [& hum]ble Servant... Godschall [who lived near Guildford in Surrey]" [?].
Mentha sylvestris Lin. [G]; M. villosa [TA]; var. Huds. Britannica? [G]. [Specimens probably diseased.]

folders.description: Origanum onites? [TA]; O. vulgare [G]. i. "This Pot Marjoram of the Gardens. Hudson says is no other than a Var: of Orig: vulgare" [JL].
Origanum onites? [TA]; O. vulgare [G]. [On reverse of label:] "Pot Marjoram commonly so call[ed]. P. Lodge [Percy Lodge near Colnbrook]" [JL].
Origanum marjorana [TA]; O. vulgare [G]. [Specimen incomplete but probably O. vulgare.]
Salvia pratensis [TA]. i. "Salvia pratensis ex horto" [JL].
Anthyllis vulneraria [TA]. i. "Anthyllis vulneraria Frequent in Norfolk" [B]; "Bryant" [JL].
Astragalus Epiglotis [TA]. i. "An Astragalus arenarius? seu quid? In Anglia prope Portsmouth inventa a D. Banks" [JL]. ii. "Astragalus arenarius" [? Banks].
Astragalus Epiglotis Linn. and A. arenarius Huds. [G]. Flora Scotica ed. 1, 400 (1777).
Genista pilosa [TA]. i. "Genista pilosa Lin: near Culford & Lachford in Suffolk" [JL].
Lathyrus hirsutus [TA]. i. "Lathyrus hirsutus near Mundenhall 5 Miles from Maldon in Essex" [JL]. ii. "Lathyrus hirsutus. an English Plant about Rochford in Essex. Clement's" [JL].
Lathyrus hirsutus [TA]. i. "Lathyrus hirsutus on the Meadows near Hornhill Ferry" [B]; "By Mr. Bryant" [JL].

Pisum Maritimum [TA]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 319. ii. "Sea Pease. Aug'. This is found upon our Sea Coasts, but not common. I gathered this Specimen between Aldborough & Orford in Suffolk, Upon the Sea Beach among the Stones, where it grows in the greatest Plenty" [JL].
Pisum Maritimum [TA].i. Cites Linn., Sp. Pl. ed. 1: 727 (1753). ii. "Portland" [JL].
Orobus tuberosus [TA]. i. "Q. an Lathyrus hirsutus, I think it can't be Orobus tuberosus" [JL].
Lathyrus palustris [TA]. i. "Lathyrus palustris on the Meadows near Hornhill Ferry" [B]; "By Mr. Bryant" [JL].
Lathyrus Sylvestris [TA]. i. "Lathyrus Sylvestris, at Brundale near Blosfield. Mr. Charles Bryant" [B; handwriting of Henry Bryant].
Medicago falcata [TA]. i. "Medicago falcata from Norfolk, Mr. Hudson" [JL]. ii. "Medicago falcata. Very plentifully on dry Banks on the South West Side of Norwich" [B].
Trifolium Millilotus officinalis [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 402 (1777). i. "Q: what Melilot. Percy Lodge [near Colnbrook]" [JL]
Ornithopus perpusillus [TA]. i. "N: 14. Comrie. June 10th" [Stuart]; "Ornithopus perpusillus" [JL]

Astragalus Uralensis [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, t., 401 (1777). i. "Astragalus uralensis from Scotland" [JL]. ii. "No. 22. Carndearg" [Stuart]; "Astragalus uralensis. In Glen Creran" [JL]. [Copy of t. Flora Scotica pasted into folder.]
Trifolium agrarium [G]. i. "An Trifol: procumbens? Percy Lodge [near Colnbrook], & pastures. June" [JL]. [Specimen onleft side of folder is T. dubium.]

Trifolium filliforme [TA]. i. "This near Slough, the Horse Road to Windsor on a sandy Place. May 6th. The Stalks procumbent, the Roots fibrous with a few tubercles on the Fibres, the Leaves smooth & striated, & emarginated. It agrees exactly with Ray's Fig: of Trifol: filliforme, except that the flowers have little or no Peduncles" [JL].
Trifolium procumbens [G]. i. "T. procumbens. This is right, tho' there is very little Difference between this & T: filiforme. Lin: says fol: non striato i.e. false" [JL].
Trifolium fragiferum [TA]. i. "This by Dr. Hope. Q: is it Scotch" [JL]. ii. "Chester & Frogmore Garden naturaly" [JL].

Trifolium Glomeratum [TA]. i. "Trifol: glomerat: Blackheath by the Green Man. Trifol: ornithopoid: grows with it. May" [JL]. ii. "Trifolium glomeratum. By no means a Scarce Plant on the South Side of Norwich" [B]; "M: Bryant" [JL].

Trifolium medium [TA]; T. alpestre Linn. and Afzelius [G]. i. "Trifolium medium Huds. T. alpestre Linn:" [JL]. ii. "T. medium between Chatham & Canterbury" [JL]. iii. "Trifolium medium Huds. Trifolium [montanum deleted] alpestre Lin. On the Banks & Bound. Mires (?) of Corpusty Field, near the Church; in Thompson's Grove at Thorpe near Norwich and indeed is very common in Norfolk" [B].

Trifolium ochroleucum [TA]. i. "Trifolium ochroleucum. Near Bury [Bury St. Edmunds], Suffolk" [JL]. ii. "Trifolium ochroleucum. This is no uncommon Plant in the Neighbourhood of Norwich; particularly in a Place called Thompsons Grove, in the village of Thorpe, laying in the Road to Yarmouth and ab! a Mile from the City—I have reserved some better Specimens for you" [B]; "Insert this in Ray" [JL].
Trifolium ornithopodioides [G]. i. "Trifolium ornithopodioides. Tuthill [Tothill] Fields" [JL].
Trifolium ornithopodioides [TA]. i. "Trifolium Ornithopodioides. Common on dry Sandy Banks on the South Side of Norwich" [B].
Trifolium pratense [TA]. i. "In the West of England" [JL].

Trifolium repens [TA]. i. "Trifolium repens. A very extraordinary variety to be found in a gravel Pit, where the Soil is generally unfavourable to Luxuriance. A Specimen of this for M: Banks, if acceptable" [B].
Trifolium scabrum [TA]. i. "Trif: scabrum for certain. It agrees w:th the Specimens in Buddle. hort. sicc. but are very small" [JL].
Trifolium maritimum 161 [G]. i. "from Mr. Banks. Trif: maritim: certe" [JL]. ii. "Aust's Passage & c." [JL].
Trifolium maritimum [G]. i. "Below St. Vincent's Rocks [Avon Gorge] & Aust's Passage [Severn Estuary]" [JL].
Trifolium maritimum [G]. i. "Weymouth" [JL]. ii. "Tri: fol: marit: from Bulls: [Bulstrode Park] by seeds" [JL];
Trifolium maritimum [G]. i. "This Specimen from Edinburgh Park" [JL]. ii. "I take this to be more of the T. striatum. a smaller sample" [JL].

Trifolium striatum [TA]. i. "Trifol: striat: Buddle's Hort: sic: Kew Green. Percy L: [Percy Lodge] Park by the Greenhouse. June" [JL]. ii. "This is what I took for the Trifolium ochroleucon but I imagine it is only T: striatum" [?]; "Certainly T: striatum" [JL].

Trifolium striatum [G]. i. "Trifolium glomeratum. Not uncommon on dry Sandy Grounds" [B]. ii. "Trifolium Striatum. var. common on dry Sandy Ground" [B]. iii. "T. striat: Inverkeithing" [JL]. iv. "Scotland. Yalden" [JL]. v. "Hoddesdon [near Hertford]" [JL]. vi. "Nash Point, Glamorganshire" [JL]. vii. "Trifol: Enfield Wash. Hartford:" [JL].
Trifolium striatum [G]. i. "This Specimen from Edinburgh Park" [JL]. ii. "I take this to be more of the T. striatum. a smaller sample" [JL].

Ervum hirsutum [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 398 (1777). i.long. Leaves & the whole Plant entirely smooth. Stipulae green on both sides. Flowers similar but more whitish, & reddish & the Unguis of the Vexillum on the Back; The Pods entirely smooth" [JL].
Vicia lutea [G]. i. "Vicia lutea. Found by Mr Wm Humphry in Suffolk, on Orford Beach, the Side next the River, one Mile from the Havens Mouth" [B]; "This is very rare, & a good Discovery" [JL].
Vicia lutea [TA]. i. "The true Vicea lutea. Physic Garden Oxford" [JL].
Folder 1. Orobus sylvaticus [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, t. 390, 1129 (1777). i. "Rum" [JL]. ii. "Clyde, Scotland" [JL].
Folder 1. Vicia sativa [G]. i. "Cirrhi trifidi. Stipulae notatae. ergo var. V. sativae potius quam V. Lathyroides" [JL].

Folder 3. Vicia sativa [TA]. i. "Vicia sativa. are these only varieties? They are both in Hedges, very common" [B]; "Bryant" [JL]; "Var: of V: sativa" [JL]. ii. "I take this to be a Var. of Vicia sativa, & not V. Lathyroides. See my Description" [JL].
Folder 5. Vicia sativa [G]. i. "Vicia Lathyroides" [B]; "Bryant" [JL]. ii. "Vicia Lathoroides both the same. Yalden" [JL].
Folder 1. Vicia sylvatica [G]. i. "Bulls: [Bulstrode Park]" [both specimens eaten away by herbarium beetles]. [JL].
Pinguicula alpina [TA]. i. "Pinguicula alpina. Lin: E Lapponia: inventur etiam in Scotia boreali. Flos albus fauce lutea" [JL].
Folder 1. Pinguicula villosa [TA]. i. "Pinguicula villosa. Dorsetshire on Pool Heath, & in Devonshire & Cornwall" [JL].
Folder 2. Not named. i. "Between Wickham & Southwick, in Bogs. Hampshire" [JL].
Sheet 1. Not named. i. "Isle of Sky" [? TA].
Pinguicula vulgaris [TA]. i. "Pinguicula vulgaris" [JL]. ii. [On reverse:] "Pinguicula vulgaris Lin: e Lapponia missa. Corolla fauce villoso-gland-ulosa" [JL].

Linum perenne [TA]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 362. ii. "Perennial blue Flax. July. This Plant is found on the Banks of barren Pastures in several Places, as on Gogmagog Hills in Cambridgeshire, on the Balks of Corn-fields about Bernak Heath in Northamptonshire, & plentifully in the Isle of Shepey in Kent, & c." [JL].

Folder 1. Linum angustifolium [G]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 362. ii. "Narrow-leav'd wild Flax. July. This is a rare English Plant but grows plentifully in the Pastures by the Sea-side about St. Ives & Truro in Cornwall. It has been found likewise in similar Places near the Sea Coast in Sussex & Kent" [JL]; "The flowers of this Sp: are not 1/2 so large as those of the Perenne, nor so deep a Blue" [TA].

Folder 2. Linum angustifolium [TA]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 362. ii. "Narrow leav'd wild Flax: July. In the Pastures by the Sea Side about St. Ives in Cornwall it grows spontaneously. These Specimens came out of Kew Garden" [JL]. iii. "Bryant" [JL]; "Linum tenuifolium. This Plant comes out of my Garden, raised from Seed of your Sending-But is seems to me to be the 'Linum sylvestre caeruleum perenne procumbens, flore & capitulo minore' - R. Syn. No. 4. p. 362 w. Huds. makes a Variety of the perenne β - The Linum tenuifolium Huds. is the variety ξ Linnaeus" [B]; "This is certainly the Lin: of Ray p. 362 no. 5 but whether L. tenuif: Lin. Quiere" [JL].
Folder 3. Linum angustifolium [G]. i. "Coast of S. Wales Glamorgansh: & Pembrokes:" [JL].

species.speciesName: Linum perenne L. subsp. perenne, Flora Europaea 2: 209 (1968)

folders.description: Linum perenne L: f: [TA]. i. Cites Miller's Dict. t. 166, f. 2. ii. "Sibirian Flax. July. This Plant is vastly taller than our English Kind, & much more branched, but has scarcely any specific Distinction & is probably no other than a cultivated Variety. It is in many of our curious Gardens" [JL].
Folder 1. Linum Radiola [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 174, 1119 (1777). i. "Penzance" [JL]. ii. "See also Tetrandria tetragynia" [TA].
Lythrum hyssopifolium [TA]. i. "Lythrum hyssopifolium Lin: Grass Poly; Small Hedge Hysop. Anglis. On Hounslow Heath. Sepr. 1766" [JL].
Lythrum Salicaria [TA]. i. "Lythrum salicaria Lin: Purple spiked Willow-herb. Anglis" [JL].
1 folder. Epilobium angustifolium [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 197, 1121 (1777). i. "Epilobium angustifolium. Grays near Henley, Oxfordshire" [JL].

Folder 1. Circaea alpina [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 80, 1115 (1777). i. "Alpine Enchanters Nightshade. July & Aug. This is one of the rarer Natives of England. It grows at the Foot of some of the Mountains in Yorkshire & Westmoreland" [JL]. ii. "Circaea Alpina. Newfoundland. Mr.Banks" [JL] [P.H. Raven identified this specimen as C. alpina].

Folder 1. Circaea lutetiana [TA]. i. "Circaea lutetiana" [JL]. ii. "Circaea lutetiana. Racemo unico. Common in our Woods. I wanted to see a perfect Specimen of the Alpina; for I have long suspected that it is only this Variety" [B]; "Bryant" [JL]; "The C. alpina differs in habit of Growth. I sent Roots of C - alpina" [JL].

Folder 1. Epilobium alpinum [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, t. 199, 1122 (1777). i. "Epilobium alpinum Lin: From Ben-Lomond in Scotland" [JL]. ii. "from Loch-Broom Mountains in Ross-shire Scotland" [JL]. Sheet 1. Epilobium alpinum [G].
Folder 1. Epilobium hirsutum [TA]; E. ramosum [G]. i. "Epilobium ramosum. Huds: Epilobium hirsutum. Lin:" [JL].
Folder 1. Epilobium montanum [TA]. i. "Epilobium montanum" [JL]. ii. "Bulls Grove [grove in Bulstrode Park]" [JL].
Folder 1. Epilobium palustre [TA]. i. "Epilobium palustre var. β Lin: In the Bogs at Virginia Water on Bagshot Heath; a large Specimen" [JL]. Sheet 1. Epilobium palustre [G].

Folder 1. Epilobium hirsutum [G]. i. "Epilobium hirsutum Huds: sed var. β. Epilob: hirsut: Rodmoor near Newent, Glocestershire" [JL]. ii. "Epilobium hirsutum. Small-flower'd hairy Willow herb. Rodmore" [JL].
Folder 1. Fumaria claviculata [G], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 380 (1777).
Folder 1. Fumaria capreolata? L: f: [TA]. i. "F: capreolata" [JL]. [Probably F. bastardii but specimen is inadequate for definite determination.]
Folder 1. Fumaria officinalis [TA]. i. "Cowleyfield [near Uxbridge in Middlesex]. Common Fumitory" [JL].
Folder 1. Chelidonium Glaucium [G], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 279 (1777). i. "Portland" [JL].

Folder 1. Papaver argemone [TA]. i. "Papaver Argemone" [JL]. ii. "Papaver Argemone. Very common all round Norwich" [B]. iii. "Hoddesdon [near Hertford]. Cornfields. July" [JL]. Sheet 1. Papaver argemone [TA].
Folder 1. Papaver hybridum [TA]. i. "Papaver hybridum. caps: globos: torosis hispidis" [JL]. ii. "Papaver hybridum. The plant was dried up when I found it" [P];"Mr. Pitchford" [JL].
Folder 2. Papaver hybridum [G]. i. "Papaver hybridum. Corn Fields in the Isle of Thanet, & near Feversham in Kent" [JL].
Folder 1. Littorella lacustris [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 571, 1129 (1777). i. "Wales. Lakes" [JL]. ii. "Plantago uniflora. Teesdale" [JL].
Folder 2. Littorella lacustris [G]. i. "Scotland by L. sides [presumably Loch of Lake sides]" [JL].

Folder 1. Plantago coronopus [TA]. i. "Plantago Coronopus var. β Huds. On Cley Beach common. Norfolk" [JL]. ii. "Mr. Yalden from Weymouth" [JL]; "cornucopia [deleted] Coronopifolia" [TA]. [Three plants grouped on one side of folder are P. coronopus; single specimen on other side is P. maritima.]

Folder 1. Plantago lanceolata β [TA]. i. "Trigyvyloaugh" [JL]. ii. "Plantago succisa? Lyon's Fasc. p. 20. N° 37. If this be the Plant w. ch Lyons means, it is a very common var. of the lanceolate, in all dry Sandy Grounds" [B].

Folder 1. Plantago major β scoparia [TA]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 314. ii. "Besom Plantain, or Plantain with spoky Tufts. in the Isle of Thanet at Reculver" [JL]. [Specimen probably a fasciated form of P. major.]
Folder 1. Plantago maritima [TA]. i. "Plantago maritima. Newfoundland. Mr. Banks" [JL].
Folder 2. Plantago maritima [TA]. i. "P. marit: Craven in Yorkshire"[Three plants marked "X" in bottom right corner are P. serpyllifolia Hose.]
Polygonum Fagopyrum [G]. i. "Polygonum Fagopyrum. In the Fields at the Black Park near Langley, Bucks" [JL].
Folder 1. Rumex digymus [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 190 (1777). i. "Greg Maillech. Rumex digymus" [JL].
Polygonum amphibium [TA]. i. "vide Octand: trygynia" [TA]. ii. "Polygonium amphibium" [JL]. [Terrestrial form.]

Folder 1. Polygonum minus [TA]. i. "Polygonum minus at Sheer near Aldbury [now Shere near Albury] in Surrey" [JL]. ii. "Polygonum minus. Tothill Fields Mr Hudson. This seems to be a hybridous Plant between Hydropiper & Persicaria maculosa it is however always patulous & reclining" [JL].
Folder 1. Polygonum maritimum? [G]. i. "Polygonum maritimum: from Abermeney Ferry in Anglesey" [JL].
Folder 2. Polygonum maritimum? an satis distincta ab avicular [G]. i. "Polygonum maritimum. from Bar in Cantire, Scotland" [JL]. ii. "Here was a bit of aviculare" [TA] [a specimen has been removed].
Folder 1. Polygonum viviparum [G]. i. "Polygonum viviparum Lin: From Killin in Breadalbane. Scotland" [JL].
Sheet 1. Polygonum viviparum [G]. i. "Ex strath in the Isle of Sky" [TA].
Rumex crispus [TA]. i. "Rumex crispus, valvulis integris graniferis, folis lanceolatis undulatis acutis ubique" [JL].
Rumex maritimus [TA]. i. "Rumex maritimus" [JL]. ii. "At Catfield on the Common, and at Brundal, 5 miles from Norwich in a Pit near the Public House. Mr. Wm Humphry" [B].
Rumex scuttellata [TA]. i. "In the road from Caerwent to Newport out of Walls, & about Bristol" [JL]. ii. "Rumex scuttellatus. Inter rejectamta hortorum?" [G].

Folder 1. Centunculus minimus [G], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 119 (1777). i. Cites addendum of Ray's Syn. ii. "Bastard Pimpernel. June & July. Upon gravelly Ground where the Water has stood in the Winter; as near the Powder Mills on Hounslove Heath, & about a Mile beyond Bracknel in the Road to Oakingham, Berkshire, by the Road Side a little before you come to the Turnpike" [JL].
Folder 2. Centunculus minimus [TA]. i. "Between Penzance & Market Jew [old name for Marazion in Cornwall]" [JL].
Folder 1. Anagallis monelli [TA]. [Specimen consists of a single flower only.]
Folder 1. Samolus Valerandi [TA]. i. "Samolus valerandi. Frequent in Norfolk" [B]; "Mr Bryant" [JL].

Folder 1. Trientalis europaea [TA]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 286. ii. "The Alpine Chickweed Winter-green. In the North of England, particularly in the Woods & Heaths about Bingley in Yorkshire. June" [JL].
Folder 2. Trientalis europaea [G]. i. "Trientalis from Mr. Bolton" [JL].

Folder 1. Pyrola secunda [G], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 219 (1777). i. Cites Ray's Syn. 363; Moris Hist. Ox. Sect. 12, t. 10, f. 4. ii. "Dented-leav'd Winter-Green. June. This is said to be found in Haselwood near S' Walter Vavasor's Park in Yorkshire. These specimens came, the one from Sweden, the other from Newfoundland. I have found it also in Scotland in shady old Beech Woods. N.B. The Antherae in this Species stand out of the Corolla, and the Stigma is lengthened beyond the Stamina" [JL]. iii. "Pyrola secunda Lin: From Newfoundland & Scotland" [JL]. Folder 2. Pyrola secunda [TA]. i. "Pyrola secunda Lin: From Newfoundland by Mr. Banks" [JL]. ii. Cites Ray's Syn. 363; Fl. Danica t. 402. iii. "This is said to be found in Haselwood... [deleted] in Yorkshire. These specimens were gathered in Newfoundland by Joseph Banks Esq. N.B. The only material Difference between this Species & the Pyr: minor consists in the Extrusion of the Stamina & Style. The Flowers lean also to one side of the Stalk, & the Leaves are more acute" [JL]. Folder 3. Pyrola secunda [JL]. i. "Pyrola secunda Lin: From Scotland near Little Loch-Broom in Ross-shire" [JL].

Folder 1. Pyrola minor [G]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 363. ii. "Common Winter-Green, June & July. I have found this in many Places in England, as in Common Wood two Miles from Halifax in Yorkshire; in a Wood half a Mile from Nettlebed call'd Sounded in Oxfordshire; In a Wood call'd Lambridge near S' Thos Stapleton's about three Miles from Henley [Grey's Court], & in many Places in Mungewell Woods not far from the same Place. I have found it likewise in Buckinghamshire in the Parish of Medenham between Henley & Great Marlow, in the Beach-Woods by the Road's Side" [JL]. Folder 2. Pyrola rotundifolia??? [TA]. i. "Common Winter-Green. June & July. In Beach Woods close by Path-Sides in Oxfordshire & Buckinghamshire, but not common" [JL]. Folder 3. Pyrola minor [G]. i. "Pyrola minor Lin: From the Woods near Little-Loch-Broom in Ross-shire. Scotland. 1772" [JL]. Folder 4. Pyrola minor [TA].

Poterium sanguisorba L. 1 folder. Poterium Sanguisorba [TA] i. "Poterium sanguisorba" [JL]. ii. Cites Ray's Syn. 203. iii. "Common Burnet. June. It is frequent on dry & chalky Pastures. It is esteemed a powerful Astringent, but is neglected in the present Practice. It has also been lately recommended as an excellent & very profitable Fodder for Cattle, but several Gentlemen who have made Experiments for that Purpose affirm that it does not answer the Encomiums bestow'd upon it" [JL].
